Award.AwardTitle: Electronic Structure of Organic Materials: Extremely Short Intermolecular Contacts
Award.AbstractNarration:
Miklos Kertesz of Georgetown University is supported by an award from the Theory, Models and Computational Methods program in the Chemistry Division for a theoretical and computational study of aromatic and heteroaromatic radicals that exhibit very intermolecular short van der Waals bonds, in the region between 1.7 to 2.9 angstroms. These short contacts are of interest for two reasons:
-Short bonds are essential for enhanced overlap and conductivity between molecular species; new properties might emerge if materials can be designed with molecules that pack significantly more closely than the van der Waals separation.
-The chemical bond is a central concept in the physical sciences: are these extremely short contacts bonds? What affects them, and can they be made even shorter than observed until now?
To study these systems, Kertesz and coworkers apply and evaluate a a variety of density functional (DFT)-based methods. They are extending a novel van der Waals density functional (vdW-DFT) developed by Langreth and coworkers to a spin-unrestricted formalism. They also employ hybrid meta GGA functionals, empirically supplemented DFT and wave function methods.

Materials with short intermolecular van der Waals bonds are very different from classical organic compounds. They exhibit anomalous electrical, magnetic and optical properties that may be exploited technologically. The ultimate goal of this project is to design a new class of organic materials with unusual metallic properties.

This work is co-funded by the Condensed Matter and Materials Theory program in the Division of Materials Research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The work centers around the analysis of “pancake” pi-stacking bonding, a special category of intermolecular interaction. Molecules bound by these interactions constitute key synthetic elements for organic conducting materials. The ultimate goal of the project is to understand this unique intermolecular interaction, describe the observed data for hundreds of such compounds, and to come up with design principles for new systems in this class with favorable predicted properties for materials design.

The literature is not yet settled about pancake bonding. Pancake bonding (term coined in Mulliken-Person’s classic book) arises between pi-conjugated radicals in a well overlapping and stacking geometry where the radical electrons partially pair. This pairing provides a contribution to the binding energy but the pairing is incomplete leading to a diradicaloid character of the bonding. The interpretation remained challenging for computational chemistry because both dynamical correlation (dispersion) and multireference correlation contribute (due to the diradicaloid character both bonding and antibonding combinations of the two singly occupied MOs, SOMOs, are active).

In our most recent papers [1, 2] we have shown that this pairing provides a relatively large binding energy at the equilibrium geometry (of the order of 15-20 kcal/mol, much stronger than hydrogen bonding). This leads to a reduction of the contact distances below the van der Waals value, so much so that in typical cases the vdW interaction overall turns repulsive due to the Pauli repulsion terms. This may seem as not surprising but it was a new insight based on high level MR-AQCC quantum mechanical computations.

It is important to understand basic interactions in the molecular sciences. Such understanding fosters new insights and stimulates new efforts to make new molecular assemblies that exploit these interactions. Since pancake bonding provides enhanced electronic overlap between molecules, better understanding of its mechanism can lead to new molecular conductors and multifunctional materials for future use. While computational modeling is not sufficiently accurate today to predict the properties of materials not yet synthesized, the reported research shows that if done at the state of the art, computational modeling can help the selection of promising candidates involving the computationally highly challenging pancake bonding interactions.

 

[1] “Study of the Diradicaloid Character in a Prototypical Pancake Bonded Dimer: The Stacked Tetracyanoethylene (TCNE) Anion Dimer and the Neutral K2TCNE2 Complex”, Cui, Z.-h.; Lischka, H.; Mueller, T.; Plasser, F.; Kertesz, M. ChemPhysChem. 2014, 15, 165-176. VIP paper.

 

[2]  “Rotational Barrier in Phenalenyl Neutral Radical Dimer: Separating Pancake and van der Waals Interactions”, Cui, Z.-h.; Lischka, H.; Beneberu, H.Z.; Kertesz, M. J. Am. Chem. Soc., 2014, 136, 5539–5542, DOI: 10.1021/ja412862n.
